sections.title: Introduction to MongoDB
sections.description: Learn the fundamentals of MongoDB, a NoSQL document-oriented database. Understand the differences between SQL and NoSQL databases and why MongoDB is widely used for modern applications.

lessons.title: What is MongoDB and Why Use It
lessons.content: MongoDB is a NoSQL database that stores data in flexible, JSON-like documents. Unlike relational databases, it doesn’t require a fixed schema, making it ideal for modern, dynamic applications.

examples.description: A single document in a MongoDB collection representing a user.

quiz.question: What type of database is MongoDB?
quiz.explanation: MongoDB stores data as flexible JSON-like documents rather than tables with fixed schemas.

quiz.question: Why choose MongoDB over SQL?
quiz.hint: Consider dynamic or evolving data structures.
quiz.explanation: MongoDB allows storing documents with varying structures, ideal for applications where schema changes frequently.

lessons.challenge: Create a sample document representing a product with fields like name, price, and categories.
tips: Think in terms of collections and documents instead of tables and rows.
MongoDB works well with JSON data used in modern web apps.

lessons.title: Setting Up MongoDB
lessons.content: Install MongoDB locally or use MongoDB Atlas for a cloud version. Learn basic commands to start the server, connect, and access the shell or GUI tools like Compass.

examples.description: Commands to start MongoDB locally or connect using Atlas.

quiz.question: Which command starts the MongoDB server locally?
quiz.hint: The daemon process starts the server.
quiz.explanation: mongod launches the MongoDB server that listens for connections.

quiz.question: What is MongoDB Atlas?
quiz.explanation: MongoDB Atlas is a fully managed cloud database service for MongoDB.

lessons.challenge: Install MongoDB locally or create a free Atlas cluster and connect using the Mongo shell.
tips: Use MongoDB Compass for an easy GUI interface.
Always secure your Atlas credentials with environment variables in real projects.

sections.title: MongoDB Basics
sections.description: Learn MongoDB’s fundamental building blocks like databases, collections, documents, and data types. Understand how to perform basic CRUD operations in the Mongo shell.

lessons.title: Databases, Collections, and Documents
lessons.content: A MongoDB database contains collections, which store documents. Documents are JSON-like structures that hold data and can have different fields.

examples.description: Create a database, collection, and insert a document.

quiz.question: What is the smallest unit of data in MongoDB?
quiz.explanation: Documents are the basic units of data in MongoDB, stored inside collections.

lessons.challenge: Create a new collection called 'products' and insert three product documents.
tips: Collections can store documents with varying fields.
Databases are logical containers and don't have fixed schemas.

lessons.title: Data Types in MongoDB
lessons.content: MongoDB supports various data types like String, Number, Boolean, Array, Date, and ObjectId for unique identifiers.

examples.code:
{
  _id: ObjectId(),
  name: 'Book',
  price: 19.99,
  inStock: true,
  tags: ['fiction', 'bestseller'],
  createdAt: new Date()
}
examples.description: Document demonstrating common MongoDB data types.

quiz.question: Which type is used for unique IDs in MongoDB?
quiz.explanation: ObjectId is a 12-byte unique identifier automatically generated for documents.

lessons.challenge: Insert a document with all the main MongoDB data types.
tips: Use ObjectId for primary keys.
Arrays and nested objects allow flexible data modeling.

lessons.title: Basic CRUD with Mongo Shell
lessons.content: Learn to perform Create, Read, Update, and Delete operations using Mongo shell commands.

quiz.question: Which command updates a document in MongoDB?
quiz.explanation: updateOne updates the first document matching the filter criteria.

lessons.challenge: Insert 3 documents in a collection, update one, query all, and delete one document.
tips: Use $set to update specific fields.
Always verify operations with find() after updates or deletions.

sections.title: Querying & Filtering Data
sections.description: Learn how to query MongoDB data efficiently using operators, sorting, projection, and limiting results to retrieve only the data you need.

lessons.title: Query Operators
lessons.content: MongoDB provides operators like $eq, $gt, $lt, $in, $and, $or to filter documents based on conditions.

examples.description: Examples using MongoDB query operators to filter documents.

quiz.question: Which operator finds documents where a field equals a value?
quiz.explanation: $eq is used to match documents where the field equals the specified value.

lessons.challenge: Write a query to find all products with price between 10 and 50.
tips: Combine operators with $and and $or for complex queries.
Always test queries with find() to check results.

lessons.title: Sorting, Limiting, and Projection
lessons.content: You can sort documents using sort(), limit the number of results, and select only required fields using projection.

examples.description: Sorting, limiting, and projecting fields in MongoDB queries.

quiz.question: Which method limits the number of returned documents?
quiz.explanation: The limit() method restricts the number of documents returned by a query.

lessons.challenge: Find the top 5 oldest users and only display their names and ages.
tips: Use -1 for descending and 1 for ascending in sort().
Projection is helpful to reduce data transfer in large collections.

sections.title: Working with Mongoose
sections.description: Mongoose is an ODM for MongoDB in Node.js that simplifies schema definition, validation, and CRUD operations.

lessons.title: What is Mongoose and Why Use It
lessons.content: Mongoose provides a schema-based solution to model your application data with built-in type casting, validation, and query building.

examples.description: Connecting a Node.js app to MongoDB using Mongoose.

quiz.question: What is the main purpose of Mongoose?
quiz.hint: It helps structure and validate data.
quiz.explanation: Mongoose allows defining schemas and models, providing structure to MongoDB documents.

lessons.challenge: Install Mongoose and connect a Node.js app to a local MongoDB database.
tips: Use models to interact with collections easily.
Always handle connection errors with .catch().

lessons.title: Defining Schemas and Models
lessons.content: Schemas define the structure of documents, and models provide an interface to interact with the collection.

examples.description: Defining a Mongoose schema and creating a model.

quiz.question: Which Mongoose object defines the structure of documents?
quiz.explanation: Schemas define the fields, types, and validations for documents in a collection.

lessons.challenge: Create a schema for a 'Product' with name, price, and category fields and generate a model.
tips: Use required fields to enforce data integrity.
You can define default values and validation rules in schemas.

lessons.title: CRUD Operations with Mongoose
lessons.content: Perform create, read, update, and delete operations using Mongoose models with simplified methods.

examples.description: Performing CRUD operations using a Mongoose model.

quiz.question: Which method creates a new document in Mongoose?
quiz.explanation: create() adds a new document to the collection via the Mongoose model.

lessons.challenge: Use the 'User' model to insert 3 users, update one user's age, query all users, and delete one user.
tips: Use async/await for cleaner asynchronous code.
Always handle errors using try/catch blocks.

sections.title: Relationships & Advanced Features
sections.description: Learn how to structure related data in MongoDB using referencing and embedding, and perform advanced analytics using the aggregation framework.

lessons.title: Referencing and Embedding Documents
lessons.content: MongoDB supports embedding documents for one-to-many relationships or referencing documents using ObjectIds for normalized data.

examples.description: Embedding keeps related data in the same document, referencing links documents via ObjectId.

quiz.question: Which method stores related data in the same document?
quiz.hint: Think denormalized data inside one document.
quiz.explanation: Embedding stores related objects directly in the parent document.

lessons.challenge: Create a 'User' schema with embedded 'addresses' array containing street, city, and zip fields.
tips: Use referencing for large datasets to avoid large documents.
Use embedding for tightly coupled data that is frequently accessed together.

lessons.title: Aggregation Framework
lessons.content: MongoDB’s aggregation framework allows powerful data processing using stages like $match, $group, $project, and $sort.

examples.description: Aggregate completed orders by customer and sort descending by total orders.

quiz.question: Which stage in aggregation groups documents together?
quiz.explanation: $group combines documents by a specified key and can compute sums, averages, counts, etc.

lessons.challenge: Use aggregation to calculate total sales per product category.
tips: Combine multiple stages in a pipeline for complex analytics.
Always test aggregation queries on small datasets first.

sections.title: Indexing & Performance
sections.description: Improve query performance in MongoDB using indexes, and analyze queries to optimize speed and efficiency.

lessons.title: Creating Indexes
lessons.content: Indexes in MongoDB improve query performance by allowing faster lookups on specified fields.

examples.description: Single-field and compound indexes can significantly speed up queries.

quiz.question: Which method creates an index in MongoDB?
quiz.hint: Used on collections to speed up queries.
quiz.explanation: createIndex() adds an index to a collection, improving query performance.

lessons.challenge: Add indexes on the 'email' field of users and 'price' field of products.
tips: Use indexes on fields frequently queried.
Avoid excessive indexing as it slows down writes.

lessons.title: Query Optimization & explain()
lessons.content: The explain() method in MongoDB shows how queries are executed, helping identify bottlenecks and improve performance.

examples.description: Use explain() to check if indexes are used and query efficiency.

quiz.question: Which method helps analyze query execution in MongoDB?
quiz.hint: Provides execution stats and index usage.
quiz.explanation: explain() shows how MongoDB executes a query and whether it uses indexes.

lessons.challenge: Optimize a slow query by adding indexes and verifying with explain().
tips: Always check query plans for large collections.
Indexes improve read performance but impact write speed.

sections.title: MongoDB with Express/Node
sections.description: Learn how to integrate MongoDB with Node.js/Express applications to build dynamic backends and REST APIs.

lessons.title: Connecting MongoDB to Express
lessons.content: Use Mongoose and environment variables to securely connect your Express app to a MongoDB database.

examples.description: Connecting a Node.js/Express app to MongoDB securely using environment variables.

quiz.question: Which library simplifies MongoDB integration with Node.js?
quiz.explanation: Mongoose is the standard ODM for connecting Node.js applications to MongoDB.

lessons.challenge: Connect your Express app to a local MongoDB database using Mongoose and .env variables.
tips: Never hardcode database URIs in your code.
Use try/catch to handle connection errors.

lessons.title: Building a Simple REST API
lessons.content: Create CRUD routes in Express to interact with MongoDB using Mongoose models.

examples.description: Basic Express routes to create and read users from MongoDB using Mongoose.

quiz.question: Which HTTP method is used to update a resource in REST?
quiz.hint: Think about full replacement of the resource.
quiz.explanation: PUT is used to update existing resources in REST APIs.

lessons.challenge: Build a full CRUD REST API for a 'Product' model with Express and MongoDB.
tips: Use express.json() middleware to parse request bodies.
Organize routes and controllers for maintainable code.
